metadata.title: Nutrition in Living Organisms
metadata.subject: Science
metadata.description: This chapter explains the different ways living organisms obtain food. It covers autotrophic nutrition like photosynthesis in plants, and various forms of heterotrophic nutrition, including how animals and parasitic plants get their nourishment.

concepts.title: Autotrophic Nutrition & Photosynthesis
concepts.content: Autotrophs are organisms that can produce their own food. Plants are the most common autotrophs. They use a process called photosynthesis, converting light energy into chemical energy. Using sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide, they create glucose (sugar for energy) and release oxygen as a byproduct.

examples.text: A mango tree using sunlight to grow and produce fruit.
Algae in a pond creating their own food through photosynthesis.
The chemical equation: 6CO₂ + 6H₂O + Light Energy → C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂

keyPoints.text: Photosynthesis occurs in the chloroplasts of plant cells.
Chlorophyll is the green pigment that captures light energy.
The food produced is transported to all parts of the plant through the phloem.

concepts.funFact: Even under the ocean, some bacteria use chemicals from hydrothermal vents to make their own food, a process called chemosynthesis!

concepts.title: Heterotrophic Nutrition
concepts.content: Heterotrophs cannot make their own food and must obtain it by consuming other organisms. This includes all animals, fungi, and some types of bacteria and plants.

examples.text: Parasitic: A Cuscuta plant absorbing nutrients from a host plant.
Saprotrophic: Fungi like mushrooms breaking down dead logs for food.
Insectivorous: A Venus flytrap catching an insect to supplement its nutrient intake.

keyPoints.text: There are three main types: Holozoic, Saprotrophic, and Parasitic.
Parasites live on or inside a host organism and get nutrition at the host's expense.
Saprotrophs feed on dead and decaying organic matter.

concepts.funFact: The Loranthus plant is a semi-parasite. It has green leaves and can perform photosynthesis, but it takes water and minerals from its host plant!

concepts.title: Nutrition in Animals
concepts.content: Most animals have Holozoic nutrition, which involves the intake and processing of solid or liquid food. This process has five steps: Ingestion (taking food in), Digestion (breaking down complex food), Absorption (nutrients move into the blood), Assimilation (cells use the nutrients), and Egestion (removal of waste).

examples.text: A human (omnivore) eating a meal with plants and meat.

keyPoints.text: Herbivores eat plants, Carnivores eat other animals, and Omnivores eat both.
Digestion breaks large, insoluble food molecules into small, water-soluble molecules.
The final step, egestion, is the removal of undigested food from the body.

concepts.funFact: An Amoeba, a single-celled organism, engulfs its food by surrounding it with temporary finger-like projections called pseudopodia!

test.question: What is the role of chlorophyll in photosynthesis?
test.explanation: Chlorophyll is the green pigment in leaves that captures the light energy from the sun needed for photosynthesis.

test.question: Fungi and mushrooms are examples of which type of nutrition?
test.explanation: Saprotrophs, like fungi, get their nutrients by decomposing dead organic matter.

test.question: The five steps of holozoic nutrition are Ingestion, Digestion, Absorption, _______, and Egestion.
test.explanation: Assimilation is the step where the absorbed nutrients are used by the body's cells for energy, growth, and repair.

test.question: Which gas is released as a byproduct of photosynthesis?
test.explanation: Plants take in carbon dioxide and release oxygen during photosynthesis.

test.question: An organism that lives on a host and gets its food at the host's expense is called a:
test.explanation: This is the definition of a parasite. The host is harmed in this relationship.

test.question: An animal that eats both plants and other animals is known as a(n):
test.explanation: Omnivores, like humans and bears, have a diet consisting of both plant and animal matter.

test.question: The Venus flytrap is an insectivorous plant because it:
options: Gets all its food from insects
Grows in nutrient-poor soil and supplements its diet with insects
test.explanation: Insectivorous plants often live in soil that lacks certain nutrients (like nitrogen), so they trap insects to get these essential compounds.

test.question: The food made by plants is stored in the form of:
test.explanation: Plants produce glucose during photosynthesis but convert it into starch, a more complex carbohydrate, for efficient storage in leaves, roots, and stems.

commonMisconceptions: Animals digest food in their stomach only.
realWorldExamples: Watering a plant to help it perform photosynthesis.
A compost pile where saprotrophs break down vegetable scraps.
